questions.question: What is the main goal of computer vision?

options.A: To enable computers to generate realistic images.
options.B: To enable computers to 'see' and interpret visual information from the world, similar to human vision.
options.C: To efficiently store and retrieve image data.
options.D: To compress image files for efficient transmission.

questions.question: Which of the following is a fundamental task in computer vision?

options.A: Natural language understanding
options.B: Speech recognition
options.C: Image classification
options.D: Time series forecasting

questions.question: What is image classification?

options.A: Locating specific objects within an image.
options.B: Assigning a label to an entire image based on its content.
options.C: Segmenting an image into different regions.
options.D: Generating a new image based on a description.

questions.question: What is object detection?

options.A: Assigning a label to an entire image.
options.B: Identifying and localizing specific objects within an image, often by drawing bounding boxes around them and assigning labels.
options.C: Enhancing the resolution of an image.
options.D: Removing noise from an image.

questions.question: What is image segmentation?

options.A: Identifying the main objects in an image.
options.B: Dividing an image into multiple regions or segments, often at the pixel level, and assigning a label to each segment.
options.C: Changing the color balance of an image.
options.D: Rotating an image to a different orientation.

questions.question: What are convolutional neural networks (CNNs) primarily used for in computer vision?

options.A: Processing sequential data like text.
options.B: Analyzing and understanding images and videos.
options.C: Generating realistic synthetic data.
options.D: Performing dimensionality reduction on tabular data.

questions.question: What is a convolution operation in a CNN?

options.A: A way to reduce the size of an image.
options.B: A mathematical operation that applies a kernel (filter) across the input image to produce a feature map, detecting local patterns.
options.C: A method for combining the outputs of multiple neurons.
options.D: A technique for normalizing the pixel values of an image.

questions.question: What is a kernel (or filter) in a CNN?

options.A: A layer that reduces the spatial dimensions of a feature map.
options.B: A small matrix of weights that is convolved with the input image to extract features.
options.C: A function that introduces non-linearity into the network.
options.D: A method for randomly dropping out neurons during training.

questions.question: What is a feature map in a CNN?

options.A: The original input image.
options.B: The output of a convolution operation, representing the detected features at different spatial locations.
options.C: A visualization of the weights learned by the network.
options.D: A map showing the importance of different pixels in the image.

questions.question: What is a pooling layer in a CNN?

options.A: A layer that increases the spatial dimensions of a feature map.
options.B: A layer that reduces the spatial dimensions of a feature map while retaining important information, making the network more robust to translations and small distortions.
options.C: A layer that applies a non-linear activation function.
options.D: A layer that performs the convolution operation.

questions.question: What are common types of pooling operations?

options.A: ReLU and Sigmoid.
options.B: Convolution and pooling.
options.C: Max pooling and average pooling.
options.D: Batch normalization and dropout.

questions.question: What are fully connected layers in a CNN typically used for?

options.A: Extracting local features from the input image.
options.B: Reducing the spatial dimensions of feature maps.
options.C: Performing the final classification or regression based on the high-level features learned by the convolutional and pooling layers.
options.D: Visualizing the learned filters.

questions.question: What is data augmentation in computer vision?

options.A: A technique for reducing the size of image datasets.
options.B: A set of techniques used to artificially increase the size of a training dataset by applying transformations (e.g., rotation, scaling, flipping) to the existing images.
options.C: A method for improving the resolution of images.
options.D: A way to compress image data.

questions.question: Why is data augmentation often beneficial in computer vision tasks?

options.A: It always makes the training faster.
options.B: It can help to improve the generalization ability of the model by making it more robust to variations in the input data and reducing overfitting.
options.C: It simplifies the model architecture.
options.D: It is only useful for small datasets.

questions.question: What are transfer learning and pre-trained models in computer vision?

options.A: Training a model from scratch on a very large dataset.
options.B: Using a model that has been previously trained on a large dataset (e.g., ImageNet) and adapting it to a new, often smaller, task.
options.C: Transferring images between different storage devices.
options.D: A technique for visualizing the features learned by a model.

questions.question: Why is transfer learning often effective in computer vision?

options.A: Pre-trained models are always more accurate.
options.B: Pre-trained models have already learned general visual features that can be useful for various downstream tasks, reducing the need for large amounts of labeled data and extensive training.
options.C: It always makes the training process faster.
options.D: It simplifies the model architecture significantly.

questions.question: What are some common pre-trained CNN architectures used for transfer learning?

options.A: RNNs and Transformers.
options.B: Linear Regression and Support Vector Machines.
options.C: AlexNet, VGG, ResNet, Inception, and EfficientNet.
options.D: K-Means and DBSCAN.

questions.question: What are some applications of computer vision?

options.A: Only used in social media filters.
options.B: Autonomous vehicles, medical image analysis, facial recognition, object detection in surveillance, and industrial inspection.
options.C: Primarily used for text analysis.
options.D: Mainly used for audio processing.

questions.question: What are some challenges in computer vision?

options.A: The lack of large image datasets.
options.B: Dealing with variations in lighting, viewpoint, scale, occlusion, and background clutter.
options.C: Computer vision problems are generally very easy to solve.
options.D: The computational cost is always very low.

questions.question: What are some ethical considerations in computer vision?

options.A: Only concerns about the accuracy of image recognition systems.
options.B: Bias in training data leading to unfair or discriminatory outcomes (e.g., in facial recognition), privacy concerns related to image data, and the potential for misuse in surveillance and autonomous weapons.
options.C: Primarily about the artistic quality of generated images.
options.D: Mostly focused on the efficiency of image processing algorithms.
